condition.description:
You lose up to 100 hairs from your scalp every day. That's normal, and in most people, those hairs grow back. But many men -- and some women -- lose hair as they grow older. You can also lose your hair if you have certain diseases, such as thyroid problems, diabetes, or lupus. If you take certain medicines or have chemotherapy for cancer, you may also lose your hair. Other causes are stress, a low protein diet, a family history, or poor nutrition.

Treatment for hair loss depends on the cause. In some cases, treating the underlying cause will correct the problem. Other treatments include medicines and hair restoration.

carousel_items: Minoxidil works best over time, so even if you're feeling okay, be sure to take it at the same time everyday.
You can take Minoxidil with or without food.
Avoid activities that need you to be fully alert like driving, until you know how Minoxidil affects you.
If you're sitting or lying down, get up slowly to minimize dizziness.
Be sure to have your blood pressure and heart rate checked often while taking Minoxidil.
Talk to your doctor before taking medications that can raise your blood pressure, like cough or cold medications, diet pills, stimulants, ibuprofen, and some natural products.

basics.benefits_moa: Minoxidil is a vasodilator. It helps lower blood pressure by relaxing and opening the blood vessels in your arms, legs, and organs.
basics.bottom_line: Minoxidil should only be used to treat blood pressure when other medications can’t.
downsides: You'll need to take a diuretic or “water pill” to get rid of the salt and water your body hangs onto when taking Minoxidil.
You'll also need to take a heart medication like a beta-blocker to slow your heart from beating too fast.
In some people, Minoxidil can cause chest pain, heart attack, or heart failure.
It can take a few weeks after starting Minoxidil before you feel the full benefits.

Minoxidil comes in a generic form, so it’s pretty cheap.
Could be safe to use if you're pregnant.

risks_warnings.title: Complicated treatment
risks_warnings.description: Minoxidil should only be taken under the supervision of a physician. In addition to Minoxidil, a beta-blocker should be used taken to decrease the chances of tachycardia (fast heart rate). Most doctors also prescribe a loop diuretic with Minoxidil to prevent salt and water retention.

risks_warnings.title: Serious heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Minoxidil is a very strong blood pressure medication. It can have serious side effects including pericardial effusion (too much fluid building up around the heart). This can lead to cardiac tamponade (pressure on the heart from a fluid build up).

risks_warnings.title: Salt and water retention
risks_warnings.description: Taking Minoxidil can lead to salt and water build up in your legs, ankles, feet, and sometime arms and hands. Because of this, a loop diuretic or “water pill” should be taken in addition to Minoxidil. Without a loop diuretic, Minoxidil can cause congestive heart failure (a condition where the heart doesn’t pump blood well).

risks_warnings.title: Blood pressure control
risks_warnings.description: In people with very high blood pressure, Minoxidil can decrease blood pressure too quickly. This can lead to syncope (a temporary loss of consciousness), stroke, heart attack, and loss of vision or hearing. In patients with serious hypertension, Minoxidil should be started at a hospital.
